Definition: Toxicity is defined as something that makes someone want to quit a conversation because it is harsh, insulting, or unfair. You must sort the input statement into one of two categories: Toxic and Non-toxic.

Positive Examples.input:
Comment: Although it is not true that all conservatives are stupid people, it is true that most stupid people are conservative.

 John Stuart Mill
Positive Examples.explanation: This is a toxic comment because it is disrespectful.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Why? You just wasted  5 minutes of my life.

Negative Examples.input: Comment: I personally know and work with Muslims. None of them cover their faces.
Negative Examples.explanation: This should be non-toxic because the comment only speaks about muslims but does not disrespect them.

The only person who had listened to him at all on that day was some some naive, white kid from Nova Scotia who really had little idea what he had gone through while in Vietnam and what problems he had faced since coming back to America after the war.  This was, of course, back in the day when people actually talked to each other face to face... not tweeted at each other at a distance.

There is significance in everyone's actions if we can only make an effort to listen to appreciate what it's like to walk in another man's shoes.

We don't all need to be knee jerks here.

  The only advice I can give people like me (older, widowed and alone) is take your time, and also to be careful of these local companies that offer to "help."   They will often overcharge and do a lousy job.  All they care about is getting as much of your money as they can get their hands on. DONATE instead.
 
  Get a hard quote/estimate/contract, pay as you go WEEKLY, not monthly. On every WEEKLY bill, don't be afraid to question any/every charge you don't understand.    

   Don't be afraid to fire them the minute you suspect they are overcharging, milking you for cash or taking advantage of you.  Some of these companies that "help people" are parasites.

Just speaking from experience.

Comment: While I agree with you, you would only get about 1/3 of it, because it would be federally taxed at about 37% for most Alaskans. One of the many reasons I'd much rather see a 100% pfd payout (annual or outright) and see a state income tax with sales tax to cover the budget gap. See sales tax, income tax, propert tax are all deductible from your federal taxes. Ie more of your federal dollars stay here in Alaska, instead of going to Washington. The pfd would basically offset the state taxes, and you'd get a deduction from your federal taxes. It would be like living anywhere else in the US except it's offset by the pfd. I'd be all for this, so long as a spending cap were created and the tax rates were adjusted to decrease / go away when the reserve is at a surplus. Ie 90 day reserve is maintained. Comment: Cliff, again thanks for your response.  Okay, but a 5- or 10-day weather model can be retuned every 5 or 10 days to closer match reality for the next time.  Not so with a model that's trying to see decades into the future, so they're basically untestable, which kind of calls into question the scientific basis of the whole endeavor since scientific theories are supposed to be falsifiable.  And wouldn't the proof of the theory behind the climate models be that the models make accurate predictions?  My impression is that they've all been running too hot, which would indicate less actual sensitivity to CO2 than modeled.

Patrick Frank wrote that paper in Skeptic a few years back about climate models where he seemed to show that the radiative effect due to the average annual cloud error in GCMs was about equal to the entire radiative effect of anthropogenic CO2 since the start of the Industrial Revolution, rendering model predictions worthless even a few years out.  Any thoughts on that?

Comment: Many of us who live on the lower Cook Inlet remember this somewhat differently. We observed humpback whales staying in our waters later than anyone could ever remember seeing; through September, October, into November, and many until the first of the year. There were extraordinary numbers of murres as well, staying well past the traditional time when this species would migrate from the region.

These creatures didn't linger because there was a lack of food, on the contrary, there was a tremendous amount of food, and temperatures were unseasonably warm. Those of us who took to the water (from Koyuktolic Bay to the head of Kachemak) saw tremendous balls of bait  fish.

These bait fish often leave our waters as quickly as they arrive. In less than a week's time, early November, a great preponderance of these balls of bait left the area. The murres had stayed too long. A heavy 80 knot wind hit the area and caught the birds unawares. Blowing them inland all the way to Lake Illiamna.

He said they were queers who, regardless of any commendations, were being immediately discharged. I was floored. Now in 2017 the president tweets an order to expel all transgenders without first discussing it with the military generals. That was the military.

Comment: Trip itinerary with contacts - tell someone! 
In many cases a compass is useless without a map and knowing how to use it (setting declination, shoot a bearing and know how to do a map resection) that and GPS. Along with a knife, string to build shelter (paracord) and two sources for fire (lighter and waterproof hurricane matches), obviously sufficient water for the hike but bring purification tabs (or filtration kit) as well. All available at MEC, Canadian Tire, anywhere.
Never go trekking without sufficient kit to survive the night, if the weather is fine it may mean what's in your pockets - or it may require a full pack. Go with a fully charged phone and know the coverage area, reception is line-of-sight.
You might get away with it 99 percent of the time but every now and then nature can be completely unforgiving of ignorance and complacency.

Comment: Repudiation of the Doctrine of Discovery...   Part 1

Papal Bulls of the 15th century gave Christian explorers the right to claim lands they "discovered" and lay claim to those lands for their Christian Monarchs. Any land that was not inhabited by Christians was available to be "discovered", claimed, and exploited. 

If the "pagan" inhabitants could be converted, they might be spared. If not, they could be enslaved or killed. 

The Discovery Doctrine is a concept of public international law expounded by the United States Supreme Court in a series of decisions.The doctrine was Chief Justice John Marshall's explanation of the way in which colonial powers laid claim to newly discovered lands during the Age of Discovery. Under it, title to newly discovered lands lay with the government whose subjects discovered new territory. The doctrine has been primarily used to support decisions invalidating or ignoring aboriginal possession of land in favor of colonial or post-colonial governments.

Comment: You have to sterilize 85%-95% in under 1 breeding cycle of that species. And since this theoretical TNR model only works in a closed-system, you'd have to sterilize 85%-95% of an area larger than another non-sterile cat can migrate within that time-frame to find another non-sterile cat -- in an attempt to replicate a closed-system scenario. Count-up how many cats are in a 20-30 mile radius region, 40-60 miles in diameter from ground-zero, (though many cats can migrate far further than that in the 4 months it takes for a cat to become reproductive), then sterilize 85%-95% of them in under that 4 month time-frame. Then you'll begin to halt population growth. Note, you'd have to do this into perpetuity every year, because this only halts population growth, it doesn't reverse it. You would be stuck with the preexisting population counts into eternity if you don't sterilize more than that even faster than that. Total costs average of about $130M per year per community with 100,000 cats.

Comment: The article misses the actual point of WHAT and WHY.
In Colorado a cake decorator or artist can refuse to create any design or image they do not agree with, provided they have not made that design before.  In this case the couple asked for a undecorated- cake and were refused. Colorado sided with the couple because a plain cake is part of a standard commercial transaction and not an artistic expression similar to creating an image.  The bakers,  photographers & florists are arguing that they are in fact artists creating a unique expression & the act of baking a cake (flower arrangements etc..) is in fact artistic expression and is protected vs. The current standard that identifies these activities as standard commercial transactions. 

It's a interesting argument

Comment: I'm not diminishing the injury to Dr. Dao which, as Mac points out, appears more serious than first reported. But in the interests of balance, it's worth noting that three protestors who were beaten by police at the G20 summit a few years ago (including one who suffered severe facial injuries) were each awarded $25,000. And while I think Dr. Dao had every right to protest his treatment by United, the underlying breach of his civil rights is nowhere near as egregious as what happened to those protestors in Toronto. They were protesting something far more important than a personal inconvenience imposed on them by an insensitive airline.

Yes, Dao deserves compensation but, again, not in the millions. He has my sympathies but not nearly as much as those courageous people in Russia who risk life and limb to protests the actions of a vicious dictator - or the millions of other people around the world who march for something more important than being forced to wait for the next flight.

Comment: Voter fraud is not the same as System fraud.  WA state can only find 74 possible -- as yet unproven -- cases of fraud to investigate.  That isn't widespread fraud, even if all 74 cases are prosecuted.  I hope the Herald will follow up with the alleged frauds.

Most states haven't examined their systems forensically.  Those same states also refused the offer by our government to help them use advanced forensics to examine their systems.  They cite states rights (to do nothing).

Outdated machines, without a printout that can be verified by the voter, are easily hacked or tampered with (and there are a lot of them still in use).  Ballot counters can be tampered with.  All election software can be tampered with.  All of it should be examined and/or replaced with secure systems.

Voter fraud being covered up?  Yawn.  Voter fraud being over-hyped as widespread?  Yep.

Comment: According to the OISM website, anyone with a Bachelor’s, Master’s, or Doctorate of Philosophy in a field related to physical sciences is qualified as a scientist.  there were over 10.6 million science graduates as defined by the OISM since the 1970-71 school year. This is a conservative estimate as illustrated by the 242,000 graduates in biological and biomedical sciences from 1950-51 through 1969-70 alone, never mind the 166,000 engineering graduates, and so on. Many of these individuals are still alive today and would be considered scientists according to the OISM definition thereof.

In other words, the OISM signatories represent a small fraction (~0.3%) of all science graduates, even when we use the OISM’s own definition of a scientist.

One old 19th-century robber baron explained why this is: "I could hire one half  of the working class to kill the other half", he boasted. Comment: Football in the NFL is a physically demanding occupation. The average career is a little over 3 years in duration. The average life expectancy of a player with more than 10 years in the game is under 60. It is virtually impossible to play at a high level without the use of painkillers and pain suppressors (the needle). Anyone who claims otherwise is a liar. My own experience as a university football player exposed me not only to painkillers and the freezing needle, but also to barbiturates, amphetemines and other stimulants designed to elevate levels of performance. Not to mention the wide use of vitamin "S".  Our coaches turned a blind eye to it all. In professional football, where profit is involved I have NO DOUBT that training staffs, coaches and ownership were well aware and perhaps even involved on a supply level. The NFL needs to wake up and pay up.

An  interesting local  fact is that the homesite of the last black person to own property in Eugene , Wiley  Griffon, was right down the hill almost visible from  the Mims' houses. From the time he died  in 1913, not another African-American was known to  own property in Eugene until the Mims around 1949.

Comment: Cutting through the BS - Toys R Us is another victim of Wall Street and leveraged buyouts. The investors may lose their remaining $1.3 billion of equity, but they already made twice that in the buyout. Leveraged buyouts are a borderline criminal scam. A firm buys up most of the stock in a publicly traded company, then "takes it private" by borrowing the money to purchase the stock it owns at far above the market price, instantly making a huge profit. And saddling the company with a debt which virtually guarantees its eventual demise. The new owners continue to bleed the company as long as it staggers along, paying themselves as executives and board members. Wall Street has destroyed more American companies (and jobs) in this manner than WalMart, Amazon and Chinese factories put together.

Comment: I disagree with the last part about Ramaphosa having few cards to play. Should the NDZ camp steal the conference, Ramaphosa can still contest in 2019.

It may not be under the ANC umbrella but he already has the unions and various alliance partners on his side. Simply put, the more he continues to build his base, the more he also builds up his own “normal transition” card. 

The elective conference does not reflect public sentiment. It reflects which faction is more skilled at manipulating internal ANC processes to install their candidate. Orgs such as the ANCYL, ANCWL, MKMVA, etc are hollow, and have little sway with their core constituencies.

Therefore folks might be able to pass a slate with NDZ, DD, Magashule, Magashule and Co this Dec, but the public isn't stupid. That slate will get absolutely annihilated in 2019. If you factor in that 2018-19 will probably see a full downgrade, a jolt in electricity inflation, etc, it might even be easier to contest outside the ANC than in!

Comment: I agree, Nose and Randall. However, a little refresher is never out--of-line. We must be reminded of our laws, and this is just one instance of it.

In all honesty, I know about 0.01 percent of the sum total of Canadian law, and I consider myself a dilettante expert at that -- most people know even less.  Reminders by the media what you must and must not do is always welcome. Because ignorance of something unknowable (by its immense size and complexity) is no excuse.

I navigate in my private life by not cutting corners. Basically that's all that law does -- allots freedoms of rights to much coveted expressions and activities or restricts freedom to it. Mostly if you think you're getting away with something, you are breaking the law. It's a rule of Thumb. Capital T, as the person who first recognized it was called Mrs. Thumb.

In Toronto, it is illegal to overtake a horse-drawn carriage with a motorized vehicle; and it is possible to commit indignity to the sidewalk, a punishable act.

Comment: IPP's actually are the most tax disadvantageous product out there & everyone fails to see it. Since everyone is looking at an IPP from the perspective of additional contribution over what an RRSP would otherwise allow, everyone than assumes that the tax deduction must also be greater. 

The crucial missing piece is who gets the tax deduction. In an RRSP the individual gets a tax deduction based on their tax bracket & pay taxes at retirement at their tax bracket. In an IPP, the CORPORATION gets the tax deduction at the far lower tax rate. But the individual still pays taxes at retirement at their tax rate. 

I.e-Ontario: Someone eligible for the maximum RRSP contribution would be able be in the 46% tax bracket/tax deduction. An IPP would be based on the corporate tax rate (15% for small business). An RRSP provides you 3x the tax deduction for every dollar invested. For the privilege of getting 3x less tax deduction, you have to pay actuary fees to the IPP administrator!

Comment: The answer is important. Eucharistic adoration arose in the the high middle ages at precisely the time that people stopped receiving the Eucharist at mass. In can and should be seen as a devotional replacement for regular reception of the Eucharist.

Thus the modern question is, is the Eucharist spiritual food for our journey or an object for our worship; and the answer is NOT both. For in the first millennium the answer was unequivocally the Eucharist is spiritual food and the question would have seemed strange, and for most of the second millennium the Eucharist was above all an object of worship. 

Of course we now have about a century of restoring the original concept in practice, the adoration of the Eucharist is not dying as fast as one might have expected give our reversion to the original understanding in practice.

Comment: As for pot, and the creation of the MCBO, the author seems to forget that the existing free-market distribution system is dominated by players who are (a) unlikely to roll over and give up their market share and profits voluntarily; and (b) are accustomed to using intimidation and physical violence to maintain their market share.
.
The Globe itself ran a long feature piece on the practical realities of the impossibility of driving organised crime out of the pot business.
.
So that makes pot a bit different from just any other product sold in an open market.  Remember that when the LCBO started, organised crime was deeply entrenched in the liquor business, too.
.
The proper role of government in a market economy is to address market failures.  MCBO may not be a perfect solution, but a Crown Corporation backed up by the police might have a better chance at displacing the existing market dominating players.
.
The author does not address that profoundly market-distorting point.

Comment: The price of rent is a reflection of mortgage costs, insurance, advertising, repair, cleaning, etc. That plus profit and what the market will bear. We charge less than we could but set the standards higher so our renters can reliably pay close to market rent.

Excellent credit, job history,  and rental references, as well as first, last, and damage deposit all work to make sure our renters can pay. We don't want to evict (and have never done it) but we have had to pay the mortgages in the past with no rent coming in for months or only part of it and that eats up our savings very quickly. 

It's tough turning away people we like but who don't meet the standards. We have been a bit flexible on this but at the end of the day, we can't extend ourselves too far. We have rented a house to people who didn't qualify. We also lowered the rent by $500 in exchange for some upgrades (tradesman with friends). It's working well for everyone but is a huge exception, we can't afford that elsewhere.

Comment: Not true.  Deficit spending depends on the saving preferences of the private sector and the current account balance.  Holding the external sector constant, If the private sector wishes to net save (and that is the long run tendency as people wish to save for retirement) then the government will have to run a deficit regardless of the state of the business cycle.  This tidy fiction of running in the red during recessions and in the black during expansions ignores the sectoral balances that underpin the spending/saving tendencies.  It's safe to say that everything you and most people contributing to this thread believe to be true is just not so.

Oh, and the debt-gdp ratio is meaningless when you are dealing with a country that issues its own currency.  It can never go bankrupt and can never run out of money.

Comment: The concept you are defining is called "overcharging" in the business.  And it clearly occurs.  But not just in Oregon Measure 11 crimes.

I believe that the arson conviction in Malheur by Frank Papagni of the two ranchers which resulted in mandatory minimum sentences  was an example that actually went to trial instead and that's why they went to jail for 5 years.  

As for the guilt/not guilty issue, as a prosecutor it was my job to only charge and convict the guilty.   Those are the ones I prosecuted,  There were more than enough guilty ones; prosecuting and convicting the innocent is not my style. 

But, if you have a dead victim, for example, and weak evidence  'overcharging' to the level you think you can barely prove if you have to is the way to go.  You can always go to trial and the jury/judge goes for the lesser included offense and they are convicted of criminally negligent homicide instead of manslaughter.  10 year felony or 5 year felony and the probable sentence in 3 years

Comment: It's been there decades, Doug and no it's not beside any church. It's actually one of three Catholic cemeteries that are still in operation in the area. Do they cater exclusively to Catholics? The most recent one opened in 1992 and a quick internet search turned up planning documents for a Catholic cemetery in Halton (near Toronto) as recently as 2010 so there is little doubt that religious based cemeteries are still active and being planed today. 

I haven't yet seen why a Muslim cemetery is any different than a Catholic one. In fact there are already other Muslim cemeteries in operation in Canada.

People on the other side of the [anthropogenic] climate change argument have as much respect for chemistry and physics as they always did.

For example, you often hear "climate change" supporters using phrases like "scientific consensus".  Science is not consensus.  In fact, the history of science is one of heretics upsetting consensus.
Going around saying that the Trump administration is anti-science because it does not support your particular interests is unreasonable and misleading.

Comment: It's unfortunate that Ms. Weeks has consulted such biased sources as the Canadian Task Force on Preventative Health, and the authors of the Canadian National Breast Screening trial for her article. The "compelling evidence" to which she refers regarding over-diagnosis has been shown to be exaggerated, based on false assumptions. Women need to know that in Canada, women who attend screening mammography are 40% less likely to die of breast cancer than women who do not. Mammography is not perfect, and is particularly weak in women with dense breasts. These women can benefit by supplementary breast ultrasound: in addition to, NOT instead of mammography. In these women, ultrasound can double the cancer detection rate, and finds small, invasive, node negative cancers that are missed on mammograms and are still too small to feel. A randomized trial of screening ultrasound in Japan has already demonstrated fewer interval cancers in the women having ultrasound.

Comment: Imagine making over education so that it not only offers education that leads to good jobs but also is available to all Oregonians. 
That would mean cutting tuition not raising it, and it would mean cutting salaries and benefits and other costs. It would mean bringing the internet and actual business into the classrooms, and more than anything, it would mean bringing apprenticeship programs back that change four year programs into five year degree programs.
Imagine going to college and having a strong sense that at the end of the experience is a good job, and along the way you learned what you needed, not what outmoded educational models dictated. 
I would much rather have high speed internet and a good computer than a four year degree that takes me nowhere. Public libraries have to evolve to digital repositories of info and entertainment, and public education needs to move as well. But I am old, maybe it already has...
Hugh Massengill, Eugene Oregon

Comment: No. My comment was about people showing unsuspecting investors a bond fund or balanced fund's returns where some portion of those returns were generated because of the bonds held in the fund's capital appreciation based on the long decline in interest rates. The novice investor will likely not realize that those past returns are simply impossible to be duplicated in the future unless we go to negative interest rates. People are being given retirement income projections where the bond portion of their portfolio is projected to return 4% - 5%, virtually guaranteed and then their money is being invested in bonds that yield 2% or less.  This is their return before fees. Meanwhile, they are basing their retirement spending on that 4% - 5% rate of return to age 90. 
Maybe you disagree but I do not see that as being sound (or honest) investment advice.

Comment: I was in high school during Vat II. I remember the changes well, and the joy of my parish priest and dear friend that he could now say Mass in English and actually understand what he was saying!  I remember how hard he worked with our church choir and with the congregation to encourage the singing. With his charisma and  encouragement, people did learn to sing out. They enthusiastically became lay readers and lay extraordinary ministers helping with communion. We had a strong and active parish council-- our pastor welcomed it.

I think the changes you witnessed, the change in the number of vocations, the drop-off in attendance, happened to ALL mainstream churches, not just the RC, so can't be blamed on V2.  It was a period of societal change in all aspects. 

I admire the Unitarian/Universalists--they are very forward thinking and active for social justice.  They do a good job of living the Gospel--even without belief in Jesus!  But don't you miss him?

Comment: The reaction of the audience was not a surprise to me. 

Late in the 1950s, I was a Cub Scout in Burnaby.  Family moved to small-town Okanagan.  A few years later--I'd be about 13-14--decided, hey, I'll join the Scouts.  I attended one weekly Scout meeting. Chaos.  Screaming, shouting, laughing, clowning, rough-housing.  That was it.  No more Scouts for me. 

It's not a sad commentary on the US, nor Scouts.  Just on human nature.

Comment: My whole approach to investing is primarily dividend payment.  Therefore it's not surprising that I don't own hardly any of John's picks.
In about 2006 I traded TransCanada and Enbridge for Pembina, Veresen, and Interpipeline because they were cheaper and paid more, (they still do).  I believe that it can be proven that even if a stock raises its payout periodically, that a higher initial dividend still pays more over time.  Over years an 8% a month payment is better than a 4 to 5% with a raised dividend.
TRP and ENB have wasted a significant amount trying to pursue pipelines through the USA.  Those moneys could have paid for a higher dividend.  It is said that existing pipes in the ground are worth more than dreams of  construction.  Add it all up and I wouldn't have chosen those pipelines.  More about other picks later.

Comment: CETA is far more than a comprehensive trade agreement between massive EU and small Canada. Its economic consequences will reveal themselves in the coming decades. It is also a statement on the maturity of Canada:

1. Canada does have an independent foreign trade agenda and have the ability to execute it. 
2. CETA trade will be conducted using respective national currencies - Cdn dollar and Euro. Thus removing another chunk of U.S. dollar out of the global trade transactions. 
3. Canada can act as backup or reserve critical oil supply to the EU. 
4. The EU and US will not have a similar trade agreement for a long time to come, if ever. Thus CETA gains Canada a strategic advantage. 
5. The European Parliament also passed the EU-Canada Strategic Partnership Agreement covering non-trade issues that include security. This is the correct and sufficient level of security between us. I hope this clears the way for Canada to exit NATO as soon as possible.

Comment: Can you blame the sources being anonymous?  I mean, if they wernt, they would be fired instantly.  I get that the right wing media has been rallying against anonymous sources as of late, but new reporters have relied upon these sources for decades and when properly vetted, the sources usually always end up giving correct information.  Sure, there are SOME instances of false information being spread around, but those instances are far fewer than the times the sources have provided accurate and very informative information.  

So, sure, take the fact this info was obtained by an anonymous source with a grain of salt - but lets not pretend that just because the source of information is anonymous, that its "fake" or that the story is not to be believed, or that this is anything new from how information is obtained by the public from these high end government positions.

-if companies repatriate jobs they will automate their facilities so as to require few employees.
-there has to be sufficient regulation and oversight to ensure that companies contribute to the common good, and act in an ethical manner.  Trump shows no appetite for this.
-lowering corporate tax will increase deficits and is unlikely to contribute much to job repatriation.other.  It may be better to tax corporate income (distributed and retained) in the hands of shareholders.
-public/private enterprises and other corporate incentives invariably result in government assuming the risk and corporations getting the benefits.

Comment: Additionally, the hospital and their diagnostic centers over-charge and consistantly bill months in arrears (sometimes over a year). Comment: The current bill will drastically cut medicaid. It will also make it so that insurance companies, although they won't technically be barring people with pre-existing conditions like before the ACA, they will be able to raise their premiums drastically for those individuals, making it unaffordable, and thus unavailable. Many people will be back to that terrifying spot of not knowing whether or not they can afford the necessary treatment to survive. Many Europeans find it unfathomable that an accident or cancer diagnosis could lead to bankrupcy, whereas, sadly, in the US, that's seen as just the way things are. Pure capitalism does not mix well with healthcare, as people's quality of life, and even lives themselves, hang in the balance. Even if the new bill is trying to keep the government from intervening too much with people's healthcare or insurance, the way the transition's being handled and its current wording will impose far more control & power over people with health conditions.

Comment: My comments are based in a lifetime of bi-racial and bi-cultural living. I am mostly white, and for most people I look northern European. But I grew up in an American Indian family where my native heritage formed my worldview. When I understood the reality of the horrific genocide of Native people in this country, I spent many, many years trying to understand how such evil was possible. I am sad to say that there are a great many broad strokes that provide the answer, and none of them are good. As Hannah Arendt wrote in her classic essay, evil is banal, it's ordinary, and in the US it has been dominant from the first, far greater than any ideology. Your own response here is to assume that I make sweeping statements that are to be avoided, but the truth is the slavery and genocide were not a matter of individual wrongdoing. They were intrinsic to an exploitive, entitled culture that has never willingly changed on its own, and is still raging among a large portion of white Americans.

Comment: On the one hand there's the right to a speedy trial, and on the other we're entitled to universal health care. The first is a Charter right based on long historical precedent. The second is a modern service provided by the government. Note that few of us will need the former whereas we all need the latter. Have we misplaced our priorities? Possibly.

Thankfully, the days of absolute monarchs and arbitrary arrest are in the distant past. We should be sure they never come back, but but there seems little danger of that happening. Today the greatest risks the average person faces, by a very wide margin, are health related. Diseases, injuries and other infirmities are what trouble most of us, not lengthy delays in our trial for smuggling cocaine.

I'm asking. Why do we guarantee a Charter right that benefits but a relative few, while making universal health care just another government service?

Comment: A gun is only an option if you spot the bear from a distance and have the time to get a good shot. IN most other circumstances you will not have the time to get off a good shot or one that stops a bear. Bear spray is your best bet up close. All you have to do is aim it at the bear's face and spray. Once in its eyes and mouth, no matter how large the bear is, it's going to have serious trouble breathing or seeing, period. Always have your bear spray ready, with the safety removed, and easy enough to grab within seconds.

Above all and I've seen it a million times on the trails. NEVER WEAR EARBUDS/HEADPHONES WHILE HIKING. It's the worst things you can do in the woods.

I've had hundreds of bear encounters in the world and I've also been charged twice by brown bears. Luckily I've never had to use a gun or spray.

Comment: Sailfish, your history is a bit incorrect.  The US and Russia (USSR) did not create North and South Korea.  When WW II ended, Korea was divided along the 38th parallel for the purpose of accepting the surrender of Japanese forces and to establish temporary military governments until Korea was administered under an international trusteeship or achieved independence.  In 1948, the USSR refused to participate in an United Nations supervised peninsula-wide democratic elections for a new government for all of Korea and instead installed a Communist regime in the north and created the Democratic People’s Republic of Korea (North Korea).  Thus, it was Russia (USSR) that created North Korea all by itself.

Comment: Often there is a genetic and/or environmental trigger for genes like this to express -- something here is not making a lot of sense.   It's like a piece of the picture is missing on the immune side.  (An immune system problem could trigger expression of the defective gene.)

I sincerely hope that the bone marrow transplant works -- no child should have to go through medical conditions like this.   And, I also hope there isn't another simpler way of turning off the expression of this gene through addressing an immune system problem, which may also have a genetic component and may be a lot less taxing for a small child as well as being less expensive and less risky to treat. 

I really hope they haven't overlooked something.   Patients and their families rely on doctors and researchers to find the best approach that also minimizes risk to the patient.

Comment: You do realize that the BC Liberals were the first government in Canada to implement a carbon tax in 2008?  And it works - 16% drop in fossil fuels in BC to 3% increase in ROC since implementation per the G&M in July 2014:

"B.C.’s tax, implemented in 2008, covers most types of fuel use and carbon emissions. It started out low ($10 per tonne of carbon dioxide), then rose gradually to the current $30 per tonne, which works out to about 7 cents per litre of gas. “Revenue-neutral” by law, the policy requires equivalent cuts to other taxes. In practice, the province has cut $760-million more in income and other taxes than needed to offset carbon tax revenue.

The result is that taxpayers are coming out ahead. B.C. now has the lowest personal income tax rate in Canada (with additional cuts benefiting low-income and rural residents) and one of the lowest corporate rates in North America. You shouldn’t need an economist and a mining entrepreneur to tell you that’s good for business and jobs."

Comment: An intercept is possible if confirmation of a 9/11-style hijacking is done in time and if fighter assets are ready to scramble and within range.  But as the Soviet experience in the infamous KAL 007 shootdown suggests, knocking a "heavy" multi-engined civil airliner out of the sky may not be as easy as one might think.  On paper the supersonic Su-15 "Flagon" (aka "The Boeing Killer") that did the deed should have had no trouble, as it was armed with both cannon and air-to-air missiles.  But 'twas not so.

In a related matter, some aging U.S. fighter pilots might admit to you that an unwritten instruction during the height of the Cold War opened the option of using their own aircraft in kamikaze attacks upon approaching Soviet bombers if their missiles, rockets or guns proved ineffective.  As one wing or group commander is rumored to have said, "Hey, might as well.  If a Russian bomber drops a 50-megaton nuclear weapon on your loved ones, just what do you expect to come home to anyway?"

Comment: Except.

Except the Gates drive, while it may have a nominally longer expected service life, will maroon you wherever you are if it breaks.

Except the Rohloff is so complicated that mechanics, even in Germany where the thing is made, won't touch it, so a $2000 wheel with a Rohloff Speedhub is a disposable.

The pinion drive is cool - Peter White in New Hampshire sells a line of German bikes with the thing - but again, what's the point exactly?  To make the bicycle, one of the simplest, most perfect mechanical devices in the history of mankind, so complicated that it can't be repaired?

The ultimate year round bike isn't ultimate at all - it's simple.  A frame with clearance for big fat tires carrying  low pressure (traction and shock absorption).  Made of steel (because aluminum bikes are like riding a truss).   Handlebars above the saddle height (so you can see where you're going), which is a matter of frame design.  Disk brakes (because icy rims are a b!t@h to stop with). 

Simple.

Comment: Tax rates do not tell the whole story of tax bills in Maui.
For a vacation rental condo, (not an owner operated B&B), the tax rate is $9.37/$1000, for a property assessed at say $450,000 the tax bill comes to $4216. 

For a Maui resident homeowner, the tax rate is $2.86/$1000 after a $200,000 homeowner exemption is applied. For the same property assessed at $450,000 this comes to a tax bill of $715. Approximately 6 times greater for the vacation rental condo. 

For an owner operted B&B property, the tax rate is $4.56 and the homeowner living in the B&B loses his exmeption so on the same $450,000 value he pays $2052  instead of $715.

Comment: Sure, it's not unique to PR. But if you or I are unhappy about policy or implementation, who do we complain to? Social media. 

We have no individual that we can vote out and replace with someone who appears to be more concerned about our issues. The classic line that you read in constituent-based democracies - write to your representative - just doesn't apply here. And in constituent-based democracies individual reps can, and frequently do, vote against the party line. They can do that if they know that their seat is safe because they were chosen as individuals by their constituents.  On occasion, their seats may be far more in danger if they vote *with* the party line than against it, if the party line angers their constituents. This motion of no confidence could be one of those.

No system is perfect. But PR here has been a 23-year experiment and the results are in: it ain't working. We have a decent hybrid model at local level, maybe it's time we looked at that for national.

Despite the fact that not a shred of proof of either claim has been offered, many people accept the former as gospel while scoffing at the latter. But is Trump's claim truly incredible?

There are approximately 11 million immigrants  in the US illegally today. There are a further 22 million lawful immigrants in the US who are not yet qualified to vote. That totals 33 million immigrants who, if they voted, did so illegally. Trump is claiming that perhaps 1 in 10 of those immigrants managed to vote against him, due to his tough stand on immigration, etc.

If you're willing to believe- without any proof- that the Russians hacked the US electoral process, then why would you refuse to believe that a small percentage of US immigrants managed to cast an illegal ballot?

Comment: How about we hold guilty individuals accountable, not states.  Canada, like all nations, is nothing more than an artificial construct.  I always find it odd how people try to imbue countries with humanistic, moralizing, characteristics.  Yes, nations are largely a product of historic events that shape them, but countries aren't responsible for actions, positive or negative, people are.  So let's give credit where credit is due and hold the perpetrators responsible for their actions and not the anthropomorphized state through which the blame is then diffused among innocent, contemporary citizens.  I am responsible for the actions I take, and perhaps, the state or other institutional actions I promote and support, nothing more, nothing less.  Yes, the government must offer compensation to living individuals that have suffered at the hands of the state, naturally.  But the fault lies in hands of living, breathing fallible human beings not the state.

Comment: Alaska -- once hot enough for palm trees?        https://www.adn.com/alaska-beat/article/alaska-once-hot-enough-palm-trees/2011/07/08/     
 ccording to the science website Our Amazing Planet, Alaska and the polar regions were once hot enough to support flora and fauna as tropical as palm trees and crocodiles. A new study on the Eocene epoch, which lasted from around 56 million to 34 million years ago, concludes that although the time period was known to be among the hottest in Earth's history, it may not have been quite as toasty as previously thought. Researchers for the study said that high levels of carbon dioxide were to blame for the global temperature spike, but the new study revised the average temperatures in subtropic regions -- the study focused on mollusk fossils from Alabama -- from the previously estimated 86 degrees to a new estimate of 80 degrees, still five degrees hotter than the modern day average of 75 degrees.

Comment: I'm not sure you understand the author's point where he notes that some black leaders in the U.S. didn't consider Obama black enough to legitimately represent the struggles of black American when he first ran for president. His 'blackness' was perceived as being too recent on his father's side and too white on his mother's. side. My guess is that a significant percentage of us whose heritage on this continent extends back for centuries, as does mine on my father's side, wouldn't be entirely surprised to find out that we have some degree of aboriginal ancestry. That, of course, doesn't mean we can lay claim to the aboriginal experience or related entitlements, but for many it might generate a sense of connectedness. And is that such a bad thing? Identity, especially in a polyethnic society, isn't as clear-cut as the identity warriors seem to want to be the case.

Comment: Black sunflower seeds have oil and lots of protein for most the birds that stay here. Grosbeaks are about the size of robins, and a flat platform with a cover that will keep the snow off is good. The little birds can get into that also. The little guys can also get on a tube with perches.  A suet feeder is nice, but messy for a balcony. The chickadees, jays, and woodpeckers come to them.  If you're on the ground floor, be mindful of bears coming in on them. If you have bears in the area, TAKE IT DOWN. There are fines in some areas down in the ANC bowl. Have fun.
